cleaned_text: Big Pharma conspiracy theories |This article is part of |[Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) Big Pharma conspiracy theories are [conspiracy theories](/wiki/Conspiracy_theories) which claim that [pharmaceutical companies](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry), especially large corporations, act in sinister and secretive ways, such as concealing effective treatments, or even intentionally causing and worsening a wide range of diseases, in pursuit of profitability, or for other nefarious reasons. [[1]](#cite_note-Blaskiewicz-1) [[2]](#cite_note-ladini-2) Some theories have included the claim that natural alternative remedies to health problems are being suppressed, the claim that drugs for the treatment of [HIV/AIDS](/wiki/HIV/AIDS) are ineffective and harmful, the claim that a cure for all cancers has been discovered but hidden from the public, claims that [COVID-19 vaccines](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine) are ineffective, and that alternative cures are available for [COVID-19](/wiki/COVID-19). In most cases the conspiracy theorists have blamed pharmaceutical companies' search for profits. A range of authors have shown these claims to be false, though some of these authors nevertheless maintain that other [criticisms of the pharmaceutical [Steven Novella](/wiki/Steven_Novella) the term Big Pharma has come to connote a [demonized](/wiki/Demonized) form of the pharmaceutical industry. [[5]](#cite_note-Novella-5) Professor of writing Robert Blaskiewicz has written that conspiracy theorists use the term Big Pharma as "shorthand for an abstract entity comprising corporations, regulators, NGOs, politicians, and often physicians, all with a finger in the trillion-dollar prescription pharmaceutical pie". [[1]](#cite_note-Blaskiewicz-1) According to Blaskiewicz, the Big Pharma conspiracy theory has four classic traits: first, the assumption that the conspiracy is perpetrated by a small malevolent cabal; secondly, the belief that the public at large is ignorant of the truth; thirdly, that its believers treat lack of evidence as evidence; and finally, that the arguments deployed in support of the theory are irrational, misconceived, or otherwise mistaken. [[1]](#cite_note-Blaskiewicz-1) In the 1970s and 1980s, the conspiracy theory was promoted by [Ann Wigmore](/wiki/Ann_Wigmore) who held that diseases, including cancer and [HIV/AIDS](/wiki/HIV/AIDS), could be effectively treated with a [raw food diet](/wiki/Raw_food_diet). In this context, Wigmore believed that the pharmaceutical industry was part of a conspiracy to keep the population at large ill. [[10]](#cite_note-wig-10) [André Picard](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Picard_(journalist)) wrote in 2009 that the internet had radically changed the nature of popular scientific discourse from being infrequent and deferential to widespread and conspiracy based: scientific debate was often supplanted by dismissal of science as being "part of some vast conspiracy". In the conspiracist world view, "Doctors, nurses, pharmacists, pharmacologists, biochemists, immunologists, geneticists and journalists are not to be trusted. They are all on the take". [[11]](#cite_note-picard-11) Research in Italy in 2016 found that nearly half the adult population believed that pharmaceutical companies hinder the development of effective medications to heal serious diseases, which according to the authors is a conspiracy theory, and that such beliefs were negatively correlated to mainstream religion while having anti-science and anti-elitism bases. [[2]](#cite_note-ladini-2) Manifestations The conspiracy theory has a variety of different specific manifestations. Each has different narratives, but they always cast "Big Pharma" as the villain of the piece. [[1]](#cite_note-Blaskiewicz-1) HIV/AIDS Since the beginning of the [AIDS epidemic](/wiki/AIDS_epidemic), many dangerous hypotheses have been put forward to explain the origin and nature of the disease. One conspiracy theory claims that AIDS was created by the [US government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States) to control and/or wipe out [gays](/wiki/Gay) and [African Americans](/wiki/African_Americans). Also, there is a cure for HIV/AIDS that is withheld from the poor. [[12]](#cite_note-12) [[13]](#cite_note-13) Other theories say that although the virus is harmful, the risks of [antiretroviral drugs](/wiki/Antiretroviral_drugs) outweigh the benefits. The drugs are said to be toxins that are spread by doctors who have been corrupted by the pharmaceutical industry. [[14]](#cite_note-14) In a 2006 column for [Harper's Magazine](/wiki/Harper%27s_Magazine), journalist [Celia Farber](/wiki/Celia_Farber) claimed that the antiretroviral drug [nevirapine](/wiki/Nevirapine) was part of a conspiracy by the "scientific-medical complex" to spread toxic drugs. [[15]](#cite_note-Schaffer-15) Farber said that AIDS is not caused by HIV and that nevirapine had been unethically administered to pregnant women in clinical trials, leading to a fatality. [[15]](#cite_note-Schaffer-15) Farber's theories and claims were refuted by scientists, but, according to researcher [Seth Kalichman](/wiki/Seth_Kalichman), the resulting publicity represented a breakthrough moment for [AIDS denialism](/wiki/AIDS_denialism). [[16]](#cite_note-Kalichmann-16) The former president by AIDS denier [Peter Duesberg](/wiki/Peter_Duesberg), introduced policies that denied treatments to AIDS patients. According to estimates this led, among other things, to more than 300,000 people dying prematurely. [[17]](#cite_note-17) [[18]](#cite_note-18) Cure for cancer A recurring conspiracy theory claims that the pharmaceutical industry has a cure for [cancer](/wiki/Cancer), but suppresses it so that they can continue to make billions on the "ineffective" treatments currently given to cancer patients. [[19]](#cite_note-19) This was believed by 27% of the American public according to a 2005 survey. [[20]](#cite_note-20) The argument is that pharmaceutical companies are slowing down research for a comprehensive cure for cancer by developing high-profit, single-purpose treatments rather than focusing on a supposed cure-all for all cancers. [[21]](#cite_note-21) Vaccines The idea that vaccines were created by the pharmaceutical industry to make people sick, or to alter [human DNA](/wiki/Human_DNA), [[22]](#cite_note-22) [[23]](#cite_note-23) has been around for a long time but has been given new life during the COVID-19 pandemic. [[24]](#cite_note-24) [[25]](#cite_note-25) The conspiracy theory that [vaccines make people autistic](/wiki/Vaccines_and_autism) can be traced back to a study published in [The Lancet](/wiki/The_Lancet) in February 1998. [[26]](#cite_note-26) [[27]](#cite_note-27) [Andrew Wakefield](/wiki/Andrew_Wakefield) claimed that there is a link between [MMR vaccine and autism](/wiki/MMR_vaccine_and_autism). The study later [turned out to be fraudulent](/wiki/Lancet_MMR_autism_fraud), and led to Wakefield being struck off the medical register. The Lancet also withdrew the article. [[28]](#cite_note-28) Although a number of studies have disproved the link between autism and vaccines, [[29]](#cite_note-29) the conspiracy theory has survived in various forms, and it has been spread by, among others, [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump). [[30]](#cite_note-30) [[31]](#cite_note-31) Other conspiracy theories suggest that vaccines are used to implant [microchips](/wiki/Microchips) for [surveillance](/wiki/Surveillance) and [thought control](/wiki/Thought_Control). [[32]](#cite_note-32) Among others, the [Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation](/wiki/Bill_%26_Melinda_Gates_Foundation) has been accused of wanting to microchip the world's population through global vaccination programs. [[33]](#cite_note-33) [[34]](#cite_note-34) [[35]](#cite_note-35) COVID-19 The [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic) is surrounded by a wide range of conspiracy theories, including the postulation that COVID-19 does not exist at all or is just a mild [flu](/wiki/Influenza). [[36]](#cite_note-36) [[37]](#cite_note-37) During the pandemic, there was a surge of conspiracies about [the origins of the disease](/wiki/Investigations_into_the_origin_of_COVID-19), such as claiming that the virus was created in a laboratory. However, strong evidence suggests that the disease-causing virus, [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2), is a naturally evolved strain belonging to the [coronavirus subfamily](/wiki/Coronavirus). [[38]](#cite_note-38) [[39]](#cite_note-39) The 2020 video [Plandemic: The Hidden Agenda Behind Covid-19](/wiki/Plandemic:_The_Hidden_Agenda_Behind_Covid-19), promotes the conspiracist claim that vaccines are "a money-making enterprise that causes medical harm". In the video, former research scientist [Judy Mikovits](/wiki/Judy_Mikovits) spread the notion that "Big Pharma", [Bill Gates](/wiki/Bill_Gates) and the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) led a conspiracy, in which they acted together as a "circular cabal" with the aim of killing Americans. [[40]](#cite_note-miko-40) The video was released on May 4, 2020, and garnered millions of views, making it one of the most widespread pieces of COVID-19 misinformation. Natural cures In the book [Natural Cures "They" Don't Want You to Know About](/wiki/Natural_Cures_%22They%22_Don%27t_Want_You_to_Know_About), author [Kevin Trudeau](/wiki/Kevin_Trudeau) claims that there are all-natural and that these are all being deliberately hidden and suppressed from the public by the [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration), the [Federal Trade Commission](/wiki/Federal_Trade_Commission), and major food and drug companies. [[41]](#cite_note-41) The book has been the focus of much controversy since its publication, with widespread allegations of fraud. [[42]](#cite_note-42) [[43]](#cite_note-43) Reception A common claim among proponents of the conspiracy theory is that pharmaceutical companies suppress negative research about their drugs by financially pressuring researchers and journals. Skeptic [Benjamin Radford](/wiki/Benjamin_Radford), while conceding there is "certainly a grain of truth" to these claims, notes that there are in fact papers critical of specific drugs published in top journals on a regular basis. [[3]](#cite_note-Radford-3) A prominent example noted by Radford is a systematic review published in the [British Medical Journal](/wiki/British_Medical_Journal) showing that [paracetamol](/wiki/Paracetamol) is ineffective for lower back pain and has minimal effectiveness for [osteoarthritis](/wiki/Osteoarthritis). [[3]](#cite_note-Radford-3) [[44]](#cite_note-44) In his 2012 book [Bad Pharma](/wiki/Bad_Pharma), [Ben Goldacre](/wiki/Ben_Goldacre) heavily criticises the pharmaceutical industry but rejects any conspiracy theories. He argues that the problems are "perpetrated by ordinary people, but many of them may not even know what they've done". [[4]](#cite_note-bad-pharma-4) [Steven Novella](/wiki/Steven_Novella) writes that while the pharmaceutical industry has a number of aspects which justly deserve criticism, the "demonization" of it is both cynical and intellectually lazy. [[5]](#cite_note-Novella-5) He goes on to consider that overblown attacks on "Big Pharma" actually let the pharmaceutical industry "off the hook" since they distract from and tarnish more considered criticisms. [[5]](#cite_note-Novella-5) He has also written, on [Skepticblog](/wiki/Skepticblog), about the general misunderstanding and sensationalizing of cancer research that typically accompanies a conspiratorial mindset. He points out that cures for cancer, rather than being hidden, are not the cures they are initially touted to be by the media and either result in a dead end, further research goals, or a decrease in the mortality rate for a specific type of cancer. [[6]](#cite_note-novella-cancer-6) Dave Roos and Oliver Childs have criticized the idea that holding back a cure for cancer would result in more profit than presenting one. [[7]](#cite_note-Roos-cancer-7) [[8]](#cite_note-cancer-myths-8) Dina Fine Maron further notes that this view largely ignores the fact that cancer is not a single disease but instead many, and the fact that large strides have been made in the fight against cancer. [[9]](#cite_note-maron-cancer-9) In 2016, [David Robert Grimes](/wiki/David_Robert_Grimes) published a research paper elaborating about the mathematical non-viability of conspiracy theories in general. [[45]](#cite_note-Grimes_p=e0147905-45) He estimated that if there were a big pharma conspiracy to conceal a cure for cancer, it would be exposed after about 3.2 years due to the sheer number of people required to keep it secret.
